characters: A SHOT OF FLORENCE IN PHONE BOOTH
LARGE WHITE BULB AT ENTRANCE OF POLICE STATION
SHOT FROM HORROR CHAMBER CAMERA TIPPED UP SHA
TELEPHONE BOOTH NEAR ENTRANCE OF MUSEUM
SHOT PHOTOGRAPHED THROUGH OPEN DOOR OF BASEMEN
TOP OF TABLE PITCHER OF ICE WATER, GLASSES NI
SHOT OF IGOR, FLORENCE AND CHARLOTTE
STREET CORNER A CROWD OF PEOPLE
COMPOSING ROOM OF THE NEW YORK EXPRESS NIGHT
A SHOT OF WINTON AT TELEPHONE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where he exhibits groups and individuals done in wax.  The figures are of historic characters and events.  The place is almost in darkness as the steel blinds  are drawn on the windows facing the street. Through  the back and side windows we see and hear a pouring  rain. At the fade in we hear the distant rumbling of  thunder, and shortly thereafter there is a blinding  flash of lightning through the unshuttered windows  showing in clear relief a brutal, sinister face, the  black hood and cowl suggesting a medieval monk. We  see, lying at the foot of the monkish figure, a  seminude figure of a woman whose back is sadly  lacerated. She is lying face down. In the monk's hand  is a knout or cat-o'-nine-tails, as though he had  been punishing her. In the background of this shot we see a workbench and  a work light. The vague figure of Igor is seen, at  work on a nearly completed bust. DOLLY UP TO A  CLOSE-UP of Igor's hands. We see that they are the  sensitive, fine hands of an artist, dexterous in  their delicate occupation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2        FULL FIGURE OF IGOR as he steps back from the be Evidently satisfied, he goes to a basin of water and  puts his hands in it and stands as though resting them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is raining and we see an occasional flash of  lightning. The figure of Worth on the opposite side  of street from museum, walking rapidly AWAY FROM  CAMERA, comes to a point diagonally opposite museum  and glances furtively about, starts toward the  entrance. When a policeman appears, he darts quickly  to a doorway, concealing himself. The officer crosses  the street and disappears along an intersecting  street. Worth makes a second endeavor to approach the  museum, when a hansom cab draws up to the curb and  Dr. Rasmussen and Golatily alight and cross the  sidewalk toward door. Worth slinks back to his hiding  place. The cab draws away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beastly hour to disturb the fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. He works late and he'll be  delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They knock at door.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: washing hands. He straightens up and glances toward door, showing annoyance, then starts toward door.  The knock is repeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rasmussen is pressing his face to glass, looks  through, and we see, through the glass panel of the  door, Igor approaching. When he glimpses his  visitors, his expression changes from annoyance to  one of extreme pleasure, and hastening his stride he  opens the door quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with slight foreign accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, my friend, this is an  unexpected pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking hands with Igor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have thought of disturbing  you but it happens the friend I told you  of is leaving tomorrow to supervise some  new excavations in Egypt, and he was  anxious to look at your collection  before going away. May I present Mr.  Golatily?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a great pleasure. I have heard so  much about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men enter museum, Igor closing the door and  locking it. Igor laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My children will become conceited that so  distinguished a critic has thought them  interesting enough to review.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worth, standing in doorway opposite museum, waiting impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor throws light switches, one at a time, each  circuit illuminating a different group. He names them  as he throws each switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney Carton on the Guillotine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of the figure. We hear Golatily's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very interestingly done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS TO figure of Sir Walter Raleigh as the  lights are thrown on this figure. We hear Igor's  voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Walter Raleigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was particularly interested in this one.  See the fineness with which he has mounted  that beard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS TO figure of Joan d'Arc, as lights are  thrown on it and we hear Igor's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan d'Arc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pity to race through such an  exhibition. One should have time to  really study them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS TO figure of Voltaire. The lights are  thrown on and we hear Igor's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voltaire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two visitors are standing at the moment beside the  figure of Voltaire. Golatily backs away from it, half  closing his eyes and studying it critically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could almost expect him to speak. I  wonder what he'd say after all these years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor joins them, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would be astonished. He is more  difficult now, to those in authority,  than even the records show. He was a very  stubborn person, I assure you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stubborn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unbelievably. For days I argued with  this fellow before I could get him as I  wanted him. But always I triumphed ...  (he laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and few people triumphed over  Voltaire. And here ...  (he throws light switch on  a peasant mother and child)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... we have something that pleases me,  though of no historic importance. It was  done because I love to model children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group is a peasant mother, two children playing at  her feet and a nursing babe at her breast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worth, as he throws away cigarette impatiently and  takes new place of concealment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men are strolling toward the figure of  Marie Antoinette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have no right to hide such genius  in a side street museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (goes to light switch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are too gracious. These things have  some merit, I suspect ... but this-- (throws switch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I am convinced, is fine.  (Joining the group.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning close to figure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even those delicate veins, the texture of  this flesh -- I have never seen anything  more exquisite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My partner believes that I should build a  horror chamber, immortalizing the hideous  crimes and criminals of London. At such  times Marie Antoinette has reassured me,  she has promised me recognition for the  devotion I gave to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She will undoubtedly keep her promise. If  you'll grant me the privilege, I'd like to  submit this work to the Royal Academy when  I get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will have won the undying gratitude  of us all.  (Glancing over his shoulder.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that not so, Marie Antoinette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they cross to door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I regret I can't spend the time I'd like  with your exhibition, but I'm going to  worry the life out of you when I come  back.  (The three laugh.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will always afford me great pleasure  to see you.  (They shake hands.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.  (To Rasmussen.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I am very grateful to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Door opens. Golatily and Rasmussen come through door.  Igor is speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much for your visit and  encouragement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They bid each other good night cordially and the two  stroll away, as Igor closes the door and pulls the  blind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men pass the spot where Worth has concealed  himself. He peers after them from the shadows, then  crosses street toward museum and walks toward door of  entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor, with the exuberance of a delighted child, runs  to the figure of Marie Antoinette and caresses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard what he said. You heard this  man who is very celebrated, what he said  of you?  (He backs away from  the figure, laughing.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ho-ho-ho, of course, you would say that.  You always told me so, of course.  (Then extending arms to include  all the figures in the gallery.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, my friends -- Robespierre,  Danton, Marat, Maximilian, Savonarola, all  of you, how will you feel to be famous  again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These figures, whom he has addressed individually in  the last speech, are all on a raised platform or  balcony, and he has turned and gestured toward each  one as he named them. He now turns to Voltaire.  Walking toward the figure and shaking his finger at  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And even you, who scoffed at immortality,  who wrote so eloquently against the  thought of immortality, you are  experiencing it in spite of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the door open and Igor turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised, questioningly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello! What are you doing here so late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear footsteps of someone approaching him as the  CAMERA SWINGS and Worth walks into picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brusquely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came back for some of the books. I am  trying to straighten out the accounts. I  don't hope to impress you, but I may as  well tell you: We haven't a farthing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly, with no great concern)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is unfortunate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right it's unfortunate! Fifteen thousand pounds it's cost me! And you say  it's unfortunate, as though I'd spilled a  spot of grog on my waistcoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (returning to workbench,  followed by Worth; Igor  shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your money may have been well invested,  my friend. Something important may come  of all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something important has got to come of  it! Do you know that the rent on this  place isn't paid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits at bench and  starts to work)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a fact?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I'm lying to amuse myself!  (Leaning over bench  confidentially.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look here, I've an idea that will get  us out of all this. We haven't twopence  between us, but we've got these.  (Draws papers from pocket,  slaps them on desk before  Igor. Igor glances at them,  then up at Worth in surprise.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire insurance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, there's our way out. A fire in this  place would give us ten thousand pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor rises slowly, unable to believe what he hears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fire! Is this your idea of humor, my  friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want the money back I've thrown into  this rubbish heap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are asking to burn these people ...  you are asking? ...  (Growing excited, takes a  few steps away from bench.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor makes a sweeping gesture that takes in the entire  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... to destroy all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not asking you anything. I'm telling  you what I'm going to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you think I will permit this, my  friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to permit it! Whose fault is it  that no one comes here? The museum at  Walston Lane does well enough, and why?  They've got Jack the Ripper, Burke and  Hare, the Mad Butcher, the Demon Barber  of Fleet Street and things people pay to  see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they are welcome to them. To  perpetuate such creatures is to celebrate  their crimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do you think I'm in this for?  (Indicating figures, changing  tone and attempting to cajole  Igor.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of it, man, a match -- a cigar stub  -- and ten thousand pounds to divide  between us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all -- let me show you how easily  it can be done.  (He strikes match and starts  toward one of the figures.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor springs and whirls him about. Worth strikes Igor  viciously and they have a terrific struggle, in the  course of which Worth seizes a spirit lamp used for  warming wax and hurls it at Igor. He misses his mark,  but the lighted lamp falls into the folds of the  draperies of one of the figures standing next to that  of Marie Antoinette. Igor screams his terror as he  dashes to extinguish the flames, and Worth,  springing on his back, overpowers him. By this time  the fire is spreading to one of the other groups.  Worth quickly snatches some of the flaming cloth from  this group and tosses it at the feet of other figures.  The figures are shown to be melting, gradually losing  form, and finally the liquid wax itself ignites with  a flash that is almost an explosion. Igor is seen to  stir, and Worth, seizing a heavy staff from the hands  of one of the figures, strikes him several times.  Apparently satisfied that Igor is helpless, Worth now  hurries to a rear door and makes his exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Worth come through door, panting and disheveled.  He starts away and then returns and locks door, after  which he runs from scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor, dazed and weak, is struggling to his feet. He  looks toward the figure of Marie Antoinette, its  draperies now a mass of flame. He dashes toward it,  catching it up in his arms, attempting to beat out  the fire. The whole room now resembles the inside of  a furnace, and as Igor, carrying the flaming figure,  struggles toward the door, a portion of the ceiling  collapses, barring his progress. He turns and  staggers toward the rear. His clothes are blazing. He  runs to a small iron trap in floor, near which is a  group tableau of Sidney Carton on the Guillotine.  Lifting the cover, he discloses an empty drain barely  large enough to permit the passage of his body. As he  disappears through trap, the rope suspending the blade  of the guillotine burns through and the knife falls,  decapitating the figure, and the head rolls across the  floor."

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN ON
dialogues.text: 19        SKYLINE OF NEW YORK (miniature) On a building in the foreground is an electric sign,  the full width of the building, which reads New York  Express. There is a huge illuminated clock dial  someplace beneath the sign. The clock shows one minute of twelve. As the picture fades in and the  minute hand jumps abruptly to exactly twelve, another  electric sign showing the numerals 1932 in red  appears immediately beneath the sign New York Express.  Simultaneous with this we hear the shrieks of sirens,  the honking of automobile horns, the screech of boat  whistles in the harbor, the ringing of bells, the  rapid firing of a pistol somewhere in the distance,  the shouting of the crowd, indicating the passing of  the old year. These sounds, in varying degrees,  continue all through the following scenes. As this  shot dissolves, the tone dissolves with it to the  single scream of a siren as we see

dialogues.speaker: STREET CORNER A CROWD OF PEOPLE
dialogues.text: An ambulance driving around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with all the windows lighted. Some windows still have  Christmas ornaments in them. The CAMERA ON CRANE  MOVES UP TO various windows. As the screaming of the siren and arrival of ambulance evidently attract the  attention of the dwellers, several people open their  windows and look out curiously. Some of them are  holding cocktail glasses, and as the windows are  opened we hear the strains of radio music and other  sounds of joyous celebrating. In the last window we  see Igor in his legitimate make-up -- not as a horror  person -- looking at something across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ambulance parked in front of it and a number of  curious people standing about. The door of the  apartment house is opened by a man in uniform, and we  see a doctor carrying a medical case coming out of  the house. A newspaper reporter runs up the steps to  meet him and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything new, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing we didn't tell you this  afternoon. The coroner confirmed our  opinion -- it was suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this dialogue, two internes carrying a  stretcher descend the steps, pass the doctor and  place stretcher in ambulance, close door of ambulance,  get on ambulance, drive away, and again we hear the  noise of the siren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of newspaper heading: THE NEW YORK EXPRESS  WISHES ITS READERS  A HAPPY NEW YEAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Single column article:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEAUTIFUL JOAN GALE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (then in smaller type)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show Girl Found Dead  On Eve of New Year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (then the story)  While the Broadway she loved prepared  to celebrate the New Year, Joan Gale, beautiful show girl, lay dead by her own  hand, it was discovered late yesterday  afternoon. A maid at the Denton Hotel,  where the butterfly girl occupied an  expensive suite, entered her apartment at noon and found her clad in pajamas,  etc., etc. (single column picture of Joan Gale)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All through reading paper we hear New York celebration  noises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23        NARROW DOWNTOWN STREET (probably West Broadway) With elevated road extending full width of street. An  old-fashioned, disreputable brick building, with an  iron grating along the edge of walk, beyond which is  an areaway and a flight of stone steps, leading to  basement door. There is also a door on the street level.  The figure of a man approaches the house. The CAMERA  SEES only his back. We hear the distant sound of the  New York celebration, and two girls, passing the man  who is walking AWAY FROM CAMERA, blow horns at him and  throw confetti on him. He does not answer. He passes  them and admits himself to house with latchkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS him through a corridor into a room as dilapidated and forbidding as the exterior of the  house. The room, evidently used as an office, is  furnished with an ancient, battered desk and chairs.  The walls are bare, and in places the paper, and even  bits of plaster, have been torn away. The figure of the man enters and throws on the lights.  He goes to the desk, picks up a phone and dials a  number, sitting in swivel chair with his back to  CAMERA. He gets his number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, is that you, Tim? ... Tim, I'm  sorry but I've got to have that tonight  ... I've got to have it.  CAMERA TRAVELS TOWARD him as he slowly turns to face it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I need it right away.  By this time we get a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and we see that it is the man who burned the museum.  All through the phone conversation we hear the muffled  shouts, the horns, etc. of the New Year celebration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's on at the gate? ... you say Joe?  ... Well, then you can get it out all right.  I'll have the truck right down there. The  harness bull down there is oke. I fixed that  this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: STREET OUTSIDE THE MORGUE
dialogues.text: A policeman walking leisurely along his beat reaches  the iron gate and glances up at the sign above the  arch, which reads Morgue. We hear the distant  shouting, singing, trumpeting. After the officer has  disappeared, an upper window of the building opens  and the hideous face of the Monster appears as he  leans out of the window following the progress of  the policeman along the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (It is necessary to give this business in detail, but  it will be played quickly as the Monster moves with  astonishing rapidity.)  The room is almost in darkness, the only light coming  from a window well upstage and at one side. We see  dimly a row of slabs mounted on wheels. They are all  occupied, the bodies being covered with sheets. The  Monster glides quickly among them with a flashlight,  turning down the sheets and inspecting the faces,  finally locating the one he seems to have been in  search of. CAMERA COMES TO A

dialogues.speaker: MONSTER
dialogues.text: bending over slab as he examines figure illuminated by  flashlight. We do not see the features of the corpse.   As the Monster straightens up, he utters a horrible  gurgling, retching murmur of joy, and we see him  clearly for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black-cloaked figure, disproportionate and  grotesque, the face a horrible formless mass of  scarred tissue. He has practically no forehead. His  face is a shriveled bald pate of seared skin and bone,  which recedes to a pointed cranium of unnatural  contour. His eyes are alight with fanaticism and  insanity. The face is a blot of drawn, unwholesomely  colored, hairless skin. He is lipless, noseless, and  what traces of human features remain are frightfully  distorted. CAMERA RECEDES TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and TRAVELS WITH him as he pushes the carriage  quickly to the back window and places it against the  sill, feet first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the window, which has a single bar from top  to bottom dividing its center. He leans out and  whistles. During all of this we have been hearing the  joyous shouts of the merrymakers. In answer to his  signal there is a single whistle from someplace below.  He throws the sheet aside and fastens a rope around  and under the arms of the corpse, which he pushes  slowly across the sill into space. After lowering the  body, there is a whistle from below. He throws the  remainder of the coil of rope out the window, but on  the opposite side of the upright bar, so that the  rope forms a double strand outside, permitting him  to slide to ground level. CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS and we  PAN WITH the Monster as he returns the slab to its  original position. He hears someone approaching and  stretches out at length on the slab, covering  himself with the sheet. The voices grow louder and  the CAMERA SWINGS, PICKING UP TWO attendants and  FOLLOWING them as they enter. One of them throws on  the lights, and they wheel another body into place  beside the slab on which the Monster is concealed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New Year's Eve ain't what it used to be.  This is only the second one tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, times are sure tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to this one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Husband slapped her full of lumps ... said she  talked too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men turn and start out of the scene. The body,  having just been embalmed, has a muscular reflex and  rises to a rigid semisitting posture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Embalming fluid makes 'em jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He returns coolly and pushes the body into its proper  position. The action causes a horrible rasping sound,  peculiar to corpses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't that just like a woman ... always  has to have the last word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS the two men as they exit in the  direction from which they came, throwing off the  lights and shutting the door after them. CAMERA PANS  BACK to the Monster as he springs from the slab, and  FOLLOWS him as he crosses to the window, climbs  through and lowers himself over the sill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing base of upright bar of window with rope  looped over. Evidently safe on the ground, the  Monster pulls one end of rope, and we see it running  around bar until the end disappears. During this insert, we hear a crescendo of horns, shouts, etc., finally dominated by the clack of a  wooden noisemaker, that blends gradually with the  myriad clicking of a number of typewriters, as we

dialogues.speaker: COMPOSING ROOM OF THE NEW YORK EXPRESS NIGHT
dialogues.text: CAMERA PICKS UP a door at the end of a line of tables,  with typewriters, where rewrite men are busy on copy,  copy boys bringing them assignments, carrying away  completed stories, etc. Sign on door reads Managing  Editor. CAMERA SWINGS the length of the lane, PICKS  UP door at opposite end of room, and with a sudden,  terrific blast of steam whistles, etc., the door  opens and the girl, Florence (Glenda Farrell),  appears through door, obviously squiffy, leading a  nondescript mongrel dog. She carries a long, cheap  tin horn. The man nearest the door glances up from  his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen of the Daily Grind: 1932  salutes you with a fanfare of golden  brass!  (Takes hand from behind her  and blows on rubber "Bronx  cheer" rattler.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men laugh. Florence produces a bottle of Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing significantly toward  managing editor's door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save your breath. Hard-Tack wants to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to see him -- he hurts my eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kiddin', he's sore as a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to dog)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move over Kelly. I'm in the dog house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you get the stag hound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not a stag hound. His name is Kelly  and he's a police dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patting the pup; others gather  around also stroking him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean police dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plain-clothes man.  (Addressing room.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, slaves, drink and be merry for  tomorrow you might be appointed  correspondent to Washington ... a fate  worse than death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Flo, cut it out. Hard-Tack is  pretty sore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't that something. The mad monk of  Manhattan. Here goes nothing.  (Crosses to door lettered  Managing Editor and, as she  exits through it, shouts over  shoulder.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to the animal cracker roar like a  lion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The managing editor (Frank McHugh), a man of about  thirty-five, not physically unattractive, but rather  grim, is seated at his desk -- an intense worker,  plainly impatient with anyone who loafs on the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In the following scene we establish that, while he  quarrels continually throughout the picture with the  girl, there is an underlying and very strong bond of  friendship and respect between the two.)  The door opens and, as Florence appears, we hear the  last few words of her preceding speech. She closes  the door, leaning against it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I live and breathe and wear spats ...  the prince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been doing experiments with Scotch and  soda again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disheveled and obviously  with an "edge")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get the news item?  (Sarcastically.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a little bird?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  (Discards sheaf of papers  and looks up.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a pleasant vacation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charming. More delightful people crippled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Consider yourself crippled --  financially. See if you can jar your  charming friends loose from enough to eat  on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you're a sure bet to place in the  bread line. There's no room on this rag  for the purely ornamental. You're easy on  the eyes and pretty conceited about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He returns to his work. CAMERA FOLLOWS Florence and  comes to a

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: as she walks down and puts her arm over editor's  shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is mama's dumpling getting tough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes her away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm through clowning. You're all washed  up. Get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straightening up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you poor ham! This is  New Year's!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, what about it? We get out a  paper just the same. Did you ever stop to  think of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, is it my fault if nothing happens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises and, taking Florence angrily by the arm,  almost drags her to the window. He points to the  street below. There is an alternating red and green  light through the window, as though it came from an  electric sign across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look down there! Nothing happening! Out of  that insane mob you say there's nothing  happening? There's a story in every person  down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florence giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With elaborate sarcasm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how does one go about getting these  human documents, may I inquire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caustically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is none of our business.  (Pushing her suddenly so  that she stumbles to door.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you bring me something for the next  edition if it's only a recipe for  spaghetti!  (Turns quickly and  sneers at her.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to door, shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick, Watson, the cookbook!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits and slams door. He looks after her angrily,  as he returns to his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Florence reenters. Sits on desk of last man she  spoke to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a sense of humor that guy has. Thinks  a hangover is a Jewish holiday. I'm fired!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you he was a sore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stories scarcer than caviar at a street  cleaner's banquet, and he says, bring me  a yarn. All I have to do is get a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whispers to her. She straightens up and looks at  him contemptuously. She crosses to door. Turning  back, she sees the mongrel she brought in and calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, come here, Kelly. I don't want you  hanging around with that guy. He's been  reading naughty stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She and the dog exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: entitled "Naughty Stories." Shows scantily attired  figure of a girl dancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at 47th Street Police Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several uniformed men seated, reading late editions,  etc. Florence enters with gay, almost rowdy  camaraderie and thumps one of the officers on the  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy New Year, Ambrose!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He straightens and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mrs. Dempsey. I don't see how  they're ever going to settle that  heavyweight argument while you're around.  (Rubbing shoulder.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florence crosses to desk and, reaching over, pulls  the magazine out of the sergeant's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy New Year, sweetheart. How's your  sex life?  (Glances at magazine.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh-oh!  (Hands it back to him.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the Homicide Squad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's every little thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. You're the first reporter in here  for two hours. You people seeing the old  year out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm people which the old year saw out.  I'm canned, fired!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kiddin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to make news, if I have to bite a  dog.  (Looks around suddenly.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Kelly! Oh, mi gosh, even he walked  out on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a story for you. You know the  Joan Gale girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unenthusiastically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she committed suicide yesterday.  That's not news. I heard about it last  year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimicking her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? Maybe she didn't commit suicide. She  may have been murdered!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No foolin' -- any suspect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know George Winton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Howard Winton's cub?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aghast)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't suspect him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't they? He's down at The Tombs right  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (threateningly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, if you're stringin' me, Old-Timer ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I string y'? They were sweeties  until a month ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that prove?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Only she may have tried to  blackmail him. You know such things have happened. Anyway, he was at her apartment  a few hours before she was found dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hotcha! Saved, one job!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches for the telephone on the sergeant's desk.  He snatches it away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Press room for yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Florence starts to door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But hold everything. Let me give you the  rest of the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns in door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it snappy, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an autopsy ordered at Bellevue  immediately. You better skip over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting through door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give this to anybody else, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she exits, she throws switch, leaving the entire  room in darkness. There is a shout of protest from the  men, which blends with the sound of an elevated train  as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small covered truck drives up and stops. A man  riding beside the driver jumps down and, glancing  quickly up and down the street, runs down the basement  steps and rings bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lattice is drawn aside and a man peers out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get it all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ... let's get it off the truck. Lend  us a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling over his shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Sparrow -- come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another figure appears, a furtive little man who  occasionally, throughout the picture, rubs hand  across nose as cocaine fiends are known to do. He  seems to be in a very nervous state. Together, the  four men remove a large oblong case from the truck  and carry it downstairs into the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a number of crates and boxes piled in one  corner, and on a plain kitchen table, center, there  are a number of bottles, glasses, etc. The four men  enter and deposit the case, which is marked Fragile  -- Handle with Care, on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a little shot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the men approach the table, CAMERA MOVES UP and we  get a CLOSE-UP, separately, of each of the four men as  they drink. They are all of the urban criminal type. As  CAMERA PULLS BACK, the truck driver and his companion  start toward door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy New Year!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you some more!  The two exit.

dialogues.speaker: BASEMENT ROOM
dialogues.text: as the two men exit. Door tender turns toward Sparrow  and CAMERA MOVES UP TO A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No use of your hangin' around here. He  told me not to give you anything tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (obviously in highly  nervous state)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he? Call him down, willya? I've  got to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door upstage opens. The two turn and CAMERA PULLS  BACK as Worth enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sparrow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I told you to stay out of here!  Sparrow crosses eagerly toward Worth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Joe. I wouldn't bother you, but  I'm all in. My nerves are all shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your nerves are not all that are going to  be shot, you sneaky rat -- you've been  talking again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worth hits Sparrow and knocks him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to door tender)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give him a deck.

dialogues.speaker: BASEMENT ROOM
dialogues.text: as door tender extracts a small parcel from drawer in  table and tosses it to Sparrow, who grabs it eagerly  and struggles to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (threateningly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And understand this, you get nothing more  from me until you show me something! And  the next time you speak out of turn,  you're going to have bad luck.  As Worth finishes speech, he slaps Sparrow's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conscious only of  the package given him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks ... thanks.

dialogues.speaker: TOP OF TABLE PITCHER OF ICE WATER, GLASSES NI
dialogues.text: Florence approaches table, pours a glass of ice water  and, before drinking it, presses it to her forehead  and temple. CAMERA SWINGS showing rest of room, which  is evidently a morgue surgery. There are several  officials, internes, a nurse, two doctors, two or  three plain-clothes men and a policeman in uniform  who is standing guard at the door. One of the plain- clothes men, who evidently knows Florence, crosses and  speaks to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feelin' tough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a case of jitters that will cop  the Pulitzer prize. If they drag this out  too long, they'll have another corpse on  their hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was called, doctor, the girl had  been dead for possibly three or four  hours.  My examination showed clearly  that she died of laudanum poisoning. I  thought at first it might have been an  accident, an overdose. Her eyes indicated  that she used narcotics frequently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was the police theory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave any message?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's why I thought death might have  been accidental.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the plain-clothes men joins the two doctors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who got the information about Winton,  Flannery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone knows they was livin' together.  But the way they fought you'd of thought  they was married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been separated quite some time, hadn't  they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He was playin' up to some other  twist. Winton's in bad because he left  there just before she folded up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if she committed suicide, with  laudanum, she probably took it in its  crude form, and we'll find it in that or  very close to that state. If someone gave  it to her, it would be diluted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could he give it to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a cup of coffee or a glass of whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door bursts open and one of the attendants rushes  in and, going directly to the two doctors, speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gale body is gone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone? What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking almost simultaneous  with the first)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The body gone! Absurd!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.  (To the attendant.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? What do you mean the  body's gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just that. It's gone -- vanished -- disappeared!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean somebody stole the body!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It got up and walked down to the  cemetery to dig up a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detectives give Florence a dirty glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We went for the body and found the slab  empty and the window to the alley open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot dog, death on a holiday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to other  plain-clothes man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Flannery! They leave the room hurriedly, followed by the  attendant. Florence, her hand to her head, sways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, oh boy! And he asked for a story. Is  his face red! She looks around, sees phone,  grabs it up and calls for a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryant two six two six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waits a moment and then jiggles the receiver  impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Operator!  (Operator answers.  Florence, sarcastically.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, my, how you have grown.  (Quickly.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you get that number, Mrs. Van Winkle!

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: The phone on his desk is ringing. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Slug ... kill that Winton story  for this! Joan Gale's body, not John  Brown's ... Joan Gale's body was snatched  from the morgue two minutes ago! I'm here  now! Yeah, there were nine or ten witnesses! Nope, they didn't talk!  They're pretty stiff. No, dope, not  drunk, they're dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can the clowning! Great! Great! Tear  down to The Tombs and get to Winton! I'll  have Harry write the first flash!  (Something she says evidently  angers him to the point that  he holds the telephone away  from him. Half angry, as though  it were responsible, he barks.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cow does that ... and gives milk besides.  (He slams up receiver.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The papers being pushed out on rack as they are  delivered from press. CAMERA PULLS BACK as foreman  picks up a copy to examine it for type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: showing scare headline describing arrest of George  Winton who is held in jail and an autopsy ordered. On  front page is a photograph of Winton. CAMERA HOLDS  for a moment on photograph, which DISSOLVES TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winton seated on the edge of his cot. CAMERA SWINGS AROUND to reveal the cell door being opened by a guard.  Florence enters and goes to boy. He is a rather  handsome, but weak, dissipated type, who arouses our  sympathy without winning our respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do. I'm from the Express.  Winton looks up. When he speaks, his sentences are  halting and broken. He's badly frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I suppose you people will crucify  me for something I didn't do.  (His voice rising  almost to falsetto.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't! You understand that! ... I  didn't do it! She -- tried before -- (Buries his face in  hands, choking sob.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sits on cot beside him,  pats his shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, old man, that won't do. You know  you're innocent until proven guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (springing to feet and  pacing back and forth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sure, that's fine. While I'm proving  my innocence, you people are going to  uncover every petty kid trick I ever did  ... you're going to write editorials about  every cocktail I ever drank. Anything that  any sane, normal person might have done  will have a sinister meaning, if I did it.  (He is almost crying at  this point, sitting on  cot.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on! Get out! I don't want to talk to  you!  (He rises and crosses quickly  as though to open door, then,  realizing that he is locked in,  leans, face against the bars,  fighting to control tears.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florence follows him and places her hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, kid. You're in a tough spot, and  you can make it a whole lot easier for  yourself if you cut out the cry-baby  stuff --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whirling, faces her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cry-baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lawyers will be on the job in a  little while, and I warn you people  anything you print about me you've  got to prove. Dad won't stand for--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your dad has stood for plenty. Now let's  get down to cases. When did you see the  Dale girl last?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a few minutes the afternoon before  -- before --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm. Why didn't you tell that to the  police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hysterically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't give me a chance. We had a  couple of drinks and she was all right  then. She seemed happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Do you remember what she said?  What did you talk about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughed and told me that we were  being silly, that we didn't care for  each other any more but we needn't  hate each other ...  (He sobs through the  finish of this speech.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... She said she wanted to be friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Was that all she said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recovering self-control  to some degree)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We planned a trip for her. I was going to send her to Bermuda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't going with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  (Paces floor, pounding palm of  hand with fist desperately.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't I take her out somewhere? But  she was laughing and seemed so happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's get back to the case in hand.  They ordered an autopsy and discovered  her body had been stolen from the morgue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his nerves quite shattered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stolen! What are you trying to do to me?  ... You're working with the police! ...  You're trying to make me say something  that can be used against me! You're  trying ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on, hold on. I'm trying to help you,  if you're on the square, and I think you  are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why are you telling me a crazy lie? ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That happens to be the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd steal her body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what they're going to ask you.  Winton seems stunned. Guard appears in door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time's up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be right with you.  (Turning, pats Winton  on shoulder.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep a stiff upper lip, kid. I  think you'll come out okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard opens the door and as she exits, we

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR AT HIS DESK
dialogues.text: He is leaning back in swivel chair, listening  attentively. We hear Florence's voice, but do not see  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole thing sounded on the up and up  to me. The poor kid is too scared to lie. He's getting a raw deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Florence, seated in chair  close to editor's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, ain't that a shame. Nice little  chappie that wouldn't harm a fly ...  everybody picking on the little fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this kid was some unknown soda jerker, they wouldn't have pinched him. But he's  George Winton and they're playing him up.  It's a Roman holiday for every paper hat  editor in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing from desk where  he has been idly scratching  with a pencil)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the goose pimples? If he wasn't  social register -- if it was somebody  like me, you'd be trying to hang him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be trying, beloved. I would  hang him! And another thing, all this  gaga about the body disappearing. Eight  bodies have been stolen in New York  within the last eighteen months. Doesn't  it seem more reasonable to hook this up  from that angle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ruin a perfectly good story? Don't be  silly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean it. I think this kid's  entitled to a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's getting a break, ain't he? He's  front page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You give me a pain!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad to hear it. When did you go in  for crusading in the cause of justice?  This lousy mug, with all the money in the  world, has had two or three nasty affairs.  He's kept out o' print because his great- grandfather was smarter than the Indians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, anyway, he couldn't have copped  that body -- he was in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think he'd be sap enough to do  the job himself. I hope they give him the  works. Even if he didn't kill the kid,  he's responsible for her death, and  they can fry him any time without  making me sore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I won't work on it from that angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you won't -- you were pretty tough  about Judge Ramsey -- a little while ago --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they never proved anything against  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except that he disappeared when things  got too hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or was bumped off by someone who was  afraid of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whooey -- he took a run-out powder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's got nothing to do with this  case. Can I handle this my way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cannot. I'm still editor of this sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you said I was fired. Well, I  quit! Give the assignment to somebody  else.  (Starts toward door.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Hey, come here, Sob-sister!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope, I'm through!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hand is on the knob. CAMERA FOLLOWS editor who  rises and, following, embraces her roughly and pats  her on shoulder as he releases her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, screwy! Do it your own way.  As he returns to desk, she takes a step after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the square, Jimmy, if you'd seen  Winton down there -- I'm not holding a  brief for him -- maybe he's a dirty pup,  but he's scared and hysterical -- and so  kinda dumb and worthless ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great! ... If he's worthless we'll give  him away as a bridge prize. Come on --  beat it. It's five o'clock. You need  some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going through door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, there's another point I want to iron  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep on it ... we'll get it tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holds picture that he drew away from him, looking at  it critically. Florence moves back of him to glance at  it. He hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your portrait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: which is a crude sketch of Mickey Mouse on horseback,  charging a windmill with a long lance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one is me? The horse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throws tobacco pouch at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here. Florence dodges it, and exits laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: held end to end, pushing ahead of them a large quantity  of confetti, bits of paper and refuse of the hilarious  night before. CAMERA PULLS BACK, revealing three street- sweepers. In the background we see the sign:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRST TIME IN AMERICA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and in front of the place, as CAMERA MOVES UP AGAIN  TO the entrance, we see a janitor sweeping off the  sidewalk. He is a strange, unwholesome-looking  character. He has swept most of the sidewalk, pushing  the collected debris into a pile in the gutter, when  his attention is caught by the protruding end of a  whiskey bottle which shows in the pile. He picks up  the bottle and sees that there is a little bit of  liquid left in it, and he drains it, drop by drop,  into his mouth. He stoops to examine the pile further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otto! Otto! Get in here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS him as he turns and goes into the museum.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: In background we see a veritable beehive of activity.  A number of workmen, including painters, carpenters,  are busy building and designing screenlike backgrounds  for the various exhibits, placing figures on platforms,  etc. In the center of the room, watching them, is Ivan  Igor. CAMERA MOVES TO A

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: He is much changed, but still recognizable as the man  we knew before the fire. His beard and hair are almost  white and have been permitted to grow to far greater  length, but the features are essentially the same,  except that when he speaks or moves his face is  strangely immobile. He is seated in a wheelchair,  which is propelled by sprocket wheels on the arms of  the chair. In order to manage this, there is a special  cup or basket attached to the handles, as his hands  are hideously deformed and practically useless for  the purpose. He is impatient and angry with the  workers, venting his anger immediately the janitor  appears. Igor propels the chair forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor, stopping, points angrily at floor immediately  surrounding some of the groups, where shavings,  excelsior and other packing material and debris are  scattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to janitor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it take you all morning to sweep  that patch of sidewalk? Come, clean up  this mess, and don't try to sweep this  trash behind those screens. I want it  removed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starts to clean up around nearest group. Igor wheels  toward another group, FOLLOWED BY CAMERA, and  addresses workmen angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, look, you fellows. You spend two  days on something that should have taken  two hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the workmen turns angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, listen, Old-Timer, they abolished  slavery in this country a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it slavery to do what you're being paid  for? I have announced the opening of this  museum tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheels angrily away. The workman laughs. CAMERA FOLLOWS  Igor as he wheels to end of museum where Hugo and Ralph  are at work putting the finishing touches on two  individual figures. Hugo is a man of middle age, with  an insane, crafty face, unkempt hair and several days  growth of beard. He smiles continually to himself as  though some secret of his own amused him. He is deaf  and dumb and when excited or angry emits strange  terrifying growls similar to the noises we heard  the Monster utter. Ralph is rather a nice-looking  youngster and seems engrossed in what he is doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT Igor comes to a stop near Ralph and sits  inspecting his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If my curiosity is not too great, would  you mind telling me what manner of animal  this is you are designing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the maids-in-waiting for that  Elizabethan group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his hands to heaven)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he isn't struck dead! This man, he  lives! It would be interesting to know,  young man, where and when you studied  anatomy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (steps back a little and  looks critically at the  figure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't seem so bad to me. What is wrong  with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything, my friend. And you hope to be a  great sculptor --  (laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great sculptor. Look -- this forearm is at  least two inches too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the composition as a whole -- I've  tried to keep a sketchy freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it is freedom to represent people with  limbs that don't match -- cripples -- you  have achieved your purpose. Anatomy!  Heaven forgive you. You must have studied  with a sideshow of freaks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA SWINGS as Igor whirls chair and sees Hugo's  piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this fellow! Look, I ask you ...  look what this cobbler is doing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph grins. Igor takes one of the crutches that ride  beside him on chair and, reaching out, pokes Hugo's  shoulder. Hugo turns with a startled growl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing with crutch to  figure which looks not unlike  Hugo himself -- shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? Are you so beautiful that  you make everything in your own likeness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo utters an uncanny sound identified with deaf-mutes.  Igor, realizing that Hugo doesn't hear him, just waves  him back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a great mercy of Providence that this  fellow cannot hear.  (Turning back to Ralph,  suddenly extends two horribly  maimed, clawlike hands toward  Ralph.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! Look at those claws! If I had those  hands of yours, I would show you the  meaning of what you are trying to do. All  those beautiful things that were destroyed  I could restore. It is a great irony that  you people without souls should have hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a truck backing in, and Sparrow, whom we first  saw at Worth's house, climbs down from the driver's  seat and enters museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor is still speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But go on, go back to work. It is hopeless  to talk to such people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly stops and turns his head. CAMERA SWINGS TO FOLLOW his line of vision and PICKS UP rear entrance  as door opens and Sparrow enters. Igor wheels chair  rapidly toward Sparrow, CAMERA FOLLOWING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got it? Is it completed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, it's here on the truck, but it's  pretty heavy -- I'll need help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns and shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otto! You and one of those other fellows!  Come help Professor Darcey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janitor comes forward, followed by two workmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And hurry, please. This figure has still  to be mounted and dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparrow exits with three men, leaving door open. Igor  wheels back toward Ralph and Hugo. He laughs  delightedly, addressing Ralph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now, my friend, you are to see  something that one can in truth describe  as art. Professor Darcey doesn't try to  keep freedom and sketchiness in his  figures. He is an artist. He works at  home, hours, when such people as you are  loafing. He is an artist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four men carry in a long, narrow box similar to  the one that was delivered to Worth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we unpack it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the workmen takes a claw hammer from strap in  overalls and starts removing the lid as Igor wheels  himself quickly toward Sparrow and the workers. CAMERA  FOLLOWS and, as the lid of the box is removed, some  burlap and other packing materials lifted out, and the  box raised on end, we see the head, shoulders and one  arm of a beautiful, lifelike figure of a girl. We  identify the face immediately as that of Joan Gale. As  the workers go about removing the rest of the packing,  Igor whirls and addresses the other workers who have  advanced and stand admiring the figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back to work! You will have plenty  of time to look at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the workers return to their various jobs, one of  them grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some mama!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Note: The museum is, in all essentials, identical  with the institution in London, the one figure  missing from the restored ensemble being that of  Marie Antoinette.)

dialogues.speaker: IGOR AND SPARROW
dialogues.text: close to wall on which hangs a photo of Igor as a  young man standing beside statue of Marie Antoinette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is exquisite -- almost as beautiful as the  original.  (points to picture on wall.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope one day to have you restore Marie  Antoinette.  (Sparrow is in a highly nervous  state, which Igor detects.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be glad to, Mr. Igor.  (Leaning close to Igor --  in subdued tone.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll have somethin' to tell you  soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have done well, and now I, too, have  something for you. Come.

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE BOOTH NEAR ENTRANCE OF MUSEUM
dialogues.text: Ralph approaches and enters it. We see him dial for a  number.

dialogues.speaker: HALL PHONE
dialogues.text: which rings and Charlotte Duncan (Fay Wray) enters  scene and answers it. We see that in stature and face  she is almost identical with the lost figure of Marie  Antoinette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.  (Laughs.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, dear. I was just thinking of  you. ... I was, too ... no, I haven't  forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better not forget or I'll cut you out  of my will. But listen, we'll have to go  somewhere close. I'll only have a few  minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67        CHARLOTTE At PHONE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go to that Little Bohemian place... .  Yes, I like the food there.... All right,  then, at twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up receiver. CAMERA TRUCKS RACK TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modestly furnished room. There is a studio couch,  right, on which Florence has been sleeping. She  straightens up, rubs her eyes, yawning, as Charlotte  turns away from phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Charlotte turns  away from phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was it? Penny ante?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wondered. Did he invite you to lunch,  or did you invite him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you wouldn't be so sarcastic about  Ralph. He's the sweetest kid I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florence throws herself on bed, full-length, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you laughing at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just had a picture of you telling a  landlady some day that you didn't have  the rent, but Ralph is awful sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see any big-moneyed boys running  after you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met one last night ... all the money  this side of Peoria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you? Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the can.  (Charlotte starts.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hoosegow! Mrs. Winton's little boy.  The Pawk Avenue Wintons, you know ...  and plenty of do-re-mi.  (Goes smoothly into melody  of "Jail-house Blues." Singing.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in the jail-house now ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Winton comes through and is led away by turnkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (addressing Winton)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Bring your stuff, you're goin'  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two prosperous middle-aged lawyers are seated near a desk talking to the official in charge. One of them is  presenting a court order for Winton's release to the  official.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and a turnkey leads young Winton into  the room. Winton crosses quickly to the attorneys,  both of whom rise, and, shaking hands with one, he  laughs weakly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister, when I say I'm happier to see  you than I ever was to see anybody in my  life, you know that it comes from the  heart.  (Nodding to other man.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, Mr. Gates?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking hands with Winton)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splendid, my boy, splendid. What do you  think you've been up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope your father accepts that statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Dad here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I talked to him long distance this  morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he pretty sore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he wasn't exactly overjoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said to get you out of trouble and  then hire someone to punch your head off.  (All three laugh.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you had lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, come on, we'll get something to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross toward door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to official behind desk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope to see you again soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit, laughing. The guard who brought Winton in  looks after the departing men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as door closes behind them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd give a year's pay to work on that  puppy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't shellac a guy when he can  put up a hundred thousand dollar bail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florence and Charlotte occupy the cab. Charlotte seems  indignant but Florence is amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't want to offend you, but,  frankly, it's none of your business. I  don't interfere in your affairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have any affairs. What do you  mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you could have a real  affair. You couldn't care for anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been in love so many times my heart  is calloused ... but I've never hit one  with dough. This love-in-an-attic isn't  my idea of a way to spend a pleasant  afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't agree with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you raise the kids -- I'll  raise the roof. I'd rather die with an  athletic heart from shaking cocktails and  bankers, than expire in a pan of dirty  dish water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can look like a chimpanzee and act  like an igorot but he must have dough -- plenty of dough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think money is the only requisite. It  happens that the poor people are happier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then marry Ralph ... you'll be the  happiest couple in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Ralph, consulting his watch, approaches window and looks out. Through window we see a cab arriving. The  two girls emerge from cab. Florence stops to pay driver.  As Ralph turns from window and starts for his hat and  coat, CAMERA PULLS BACK TO A FULL SHOT. Ralph gets hat  and coat and starts toward door. Igor, who has been  near the front of museum, wheels out in front of Ralph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where do you think you are going, my  good friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To lunch, you say. I am having coffee and  sandwiches sent in. We are not leaving  until we have everything ready for the  opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I have some friends waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is unfortunate. They will have to  wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will only be gone about half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you leave before the work is done, you  will be gone for a much longer period ...  you will be gone for good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll tell them. They're right  here in front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph exits and CAMERA FOLLOWS him through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Ralph enters to Charlotte and, taking both her  hands, kisses her lightly on cheek. He speaks to  Florence, who is standing beside Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Florence. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, honey-bunch, I'm sorry -- I'm going  to have to disappoint you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry -- she'll get used to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She strolls up toward museum door, looking through it  at interior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disappoint me? Why, what do you mean,  dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you see, the old chap is pretty  anxious to open on schedule. All of his  advertising announced the opening tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ralph continues his explanation to Charlotte, CAMERA TRUCKS UP BEHIND Florence, and OVER HER SHOULDER THROUGH  glass panel we see interior of museum with the various  figures.
